properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall between 10 and 20 cm expected. An intense low pressure system will move onto the central coast of BC this evening and then cross the northern interior tonight. North of the low, heavy snow is expected. Mixed rain and snow over Terrace and Kitimat will become snow heavy at times this afternoon. Further inland, snow will continue for Bulkley Valley and the Lakes as well as Pine Pass. The heaviest snow is expected this evening before tapering to flurries overnight. Total snowfall amounts are forecast to be near 15 to 20 cm closer to the coast and 10 to 15 cm inland. Over BC North Peace River, snow will begin this evening and 10 cm is expected before ending early Saturday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T14:43:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-31T22:44:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1351088694.2020
Area: Bulkley Valley, Lakes District, B.C. North Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very gusty winds expected in the Fraser Canyon. A strong storm system continues to affect southwestern BC. Extremely strong winds aloft will lead to a steep pressure gradient along the Fraser Canyon. Southerly winds with gusts of 90 km/h are possible at times for tonight into Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall between 10 and 20 cm expected. An intense low pressure system will move onto the central coast of BC today and then cross the northern interior tonight. North of the low, heavy snow is expected. Rain over Terrace and Kitimat will change to snow this afternoon. Further inland, snow will begin this afternoon for Bulkley Valley and the Lakes. The heaviest snow is expected this evening before tapering to flurries overnight. Total snowfall amounts are forecast to be near 15 to 20 cm closer to the coast and 10 to 15 cm inland. Over Pine Pass, snow will begin later this afternoon and 10 cm is expected before ending early Saturday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Localized areas of dense fog have been reported over the regions. As a result, visibility could be reduced to near zero tonight and overnight. Due to freezing temperatures untreated roads could also be icy. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-02T02:32:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-01-31T20:32:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4236721310.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Weekend snowfall. Total snowfall: potentially 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 60 km/h possible. Locations: eastern Nova Scotia. Time span: late Saturday afternoon to early Sunday morning. Remarks: A developing storm over the Atlantic Ocean will affect parts of Nova Scotia on Saturday night. Snow is expected to spread across the southern half of mainland Nova Scotia on Saturday afternoon, with most of the accumulation expected Saturday night. Snowfall warnings have been issued for Antigonish County, Guysborough County, and Cape Breton, but the latest forecast guidance is indicating much lower snowfall accumulations than previously expected further to the west. In addition, rain will likely mix with the snow along the Atlantic coast before the precipitation ends early Sunday morning, further reducing snowfall amounts there. There is still some uncertainty in the track of this system, and a shift to the northwest could increase the snowfall over central Nova Scotia. Additional information will be provided as the system approaches. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T18:38:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T02:39:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0691749751.2020
Area: Colchester County North, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. Concentrations of fine particulate matter are high and will remain so overnight tonight, through Saturday, and possibly on Sunday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are occurring along the Icefields Parkway. A long duration heavy snowfall event will intensify this evening and end Saturday evening. Total snowfall amounts will be between 30 and 50 cm, with locally upwards of 70 cm possible. Strong winds will accompany the snow, which will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow at times, especially over exposed areas. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T14:23:32-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An intense low pressure system will bring southwest winds of 90 km/h to exposed coastal sections of the central coast late this afternoon and this evening. Winds will veer and ease to northwest 50 to 70 km/h in the wake of the low. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential significant snowfall and wind expected. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h with possibly gusts to 100 km/h. Locations: southeastern coastal Labrador. Time span: Sunday night through to overnight Monday. Remarks: Snow, strong north to northwesterly winds, and blowing snow are expected to develop Sunday night. Visibility will likely be near zero in blowing snow along exposed areas of the coast. Snow is expected to diminish to flurries by Monday evening but the strong winds will likely continue into Tuesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain, and wind is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Total rainfall: 15 to 30 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except locally 100 km/h. Locations: From Bay D'Espoir to Bonavista and all areas southeast. Time span: Sunday morning through to Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Sunday morning before changing to rain Sunday afternoon. Strong southeasterly winds will also develop Sunday. Rain combined with mild temperatures has the potential to cause localized flooding, especially given the large existing snow pack. There remains some uncertainty regarding total precipitation amounts and the public is advised to monitor future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-01T17:52:39-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. An intense low pressure system with subtropical moisture has brought heavy rain to most of the south coast since Thursday night. Parts of the south coast regions have received 40 to 80 mm of rain during the last 24 hours. Heavy rain will continue tonight as the cold front associated with the system crosses the south coast. Additional rainfall amounts of 40 to 50 mm are expected for most south coast regions by Saturday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T16:13:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T00:14:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0639736611.2020

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. An area of freezing drizzle has developed over northeastern Manitoba. The freezing drizzle is expected to persist this evening before dissipating overnight. ### Freezing drizzle can produce thin, hard-to-detect layers of ice. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. An intense low pressure system with subtropical moisture has brought heavy rain to the region. Since last night 30 to 50 mm of rain has fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 30 to 40 mm are expected tonight. Rain will ease Saturday morning as the system exits the area. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. Concentrations of fine particulate matter are high and will remain so overnight tonight, through Saturday, and possibly on Sunday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-02T02:35:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-01-31T20:36:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3588070095.2020
Area: Louiseville area, Matawin - Mauricie National Park area, Lac-aux-Sables area, Shawinigan area, Sainte-Anne-de-la-Pérade area, Trois-Rivières area, Bécancour - Villeroy area, Victoriaville area, Nicolet area, Drummondville area

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An intense low pressure system will continue to bring southwest winds of 80 km/h to the west coast of Vancouver Island this evening. Winds will ease to 40 to 60 km/h late this evening in the wake of the low. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T09:14:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T00:16:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1188529023.2020
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will continue to give snow heavy at times to Rogers Pass this evening. The snow will slowly transition to rain through the night as snow levels rise. Additional snow accumulations of 5 to 10 cm can be expected before the snow completely changes to rain later tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T15:24:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T00:42:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1533418225.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rain tonight. A storm system continues to bring heavy rain to the south coast tonight. Extremely strong southwesterly winds aloft will lead to precipitation spilling over the coastal mountains into the southern Fraser Canyon. Heavy rain over southern Fraser Canyon will result in 30 to 40 mm tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and wind expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm with locally higher amounts likely. Maximum wind gusts: near 80 km/h . Locations: From Burgeo to the northeast coast and all areas northwest. Time span: Sunday morning through to Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Sunday morning, and then transition briefly through rain or drizzle for areas east of central Newfoundland Sunday night. Some uncertainty remains regarding the location of the highest snowfall accumulations, however it seems more likely that the maximum will fall somewhere over the western half of the island. The public is advised to monitor future forecasts for updates on this system. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-01T17:52:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T01:53:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2254407571.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Weekend snowfall. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 60 km/h possible. Locations: eastern mainland and Cape Breton. Time span: Saturday night ending early Sunday. Remarks: A developing storm over the Atlantic Ocean will spread snow across eastern Nova Scotia on Saturday evening. Most of the accumulation is expected to occur on Saturday night, with the highest snowfall totals expected over Guysborough, Richmond and Sydney counties. Rain will likely mix with the snow along the Atlantic coast before the precipitation ends early Sunday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T18:31:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T02:32:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1616074656.2020
